The company has raised its revenue outlook to a range of $157 million to $177 million for the next five years.

articles.title: Meta AI gets two new models as Meta releases Llama 4
articles.author: Wes Davis
articles.summary: Llama 4 is Meta's newest collection of AI models that now power Meta AI on the web and in WhatsApp, Messenger, and Instagram Direct. Llama 4 Scout is a small model capable of 'fitting in a single Nvidia H100 GPU' and Maverick is more akin to GPT-4o and Gemini 2.0 Flash. The company is in the process of training its new Behemoth model, which is already 'already the highest performing base model in the world'

articles.title: A stroke survivor speaks again with the help of an experimental brain-computer implant
articles.author: LAURA UNGAR
articles.summary: Scientists have developed a device that can translate thoughts about speech into spoken words in real time. The device was tested on a 47-year-old woman with quadriplegia who couldn't speak for 18 years after a stroke. She had it implanted in her brain during surgery as part of a clinical trial.

articles.title: Report: AI Threatens Africa's Labor-Outsourcing Market
articles.author: Sema
articles.summary: Artificial intelligence threatens to shrink Africa's labor-outsourcing market. Customer experience roles account for nearly half of outsourcing roles, followed by finance and accounting tasks. Jobs held by women are most vulnerable. Africa's business outsourcing market is still projected to generate $35 billion by 2028 compared to $17 billion in 2022.

articles.title: Go back to the Grid in TRON: Ares trailer
articles.author: Ars Technica
articles.summary: An AI program enters the real world in TRON: Ares. Disney's 1982 cult science fiction film, TRON, had a huge influence on both the film industry and the society at large. It combined live action with what were then called "the medium of animation".

articles.title: Thread by @Hesamation on Thread Reader App
articles.summary: Researchers from Meta, Yale, Stanford, Google DeepMind, and Microsoft have written a 264-page book on Agents. They compared the agent's brain to the human brain and found that the brain is more energy-efficient and learns continuously, whereas the agent is static and its perception is limited to textual and vision data. Emotions are a deep aspect of humans, helping them with social interactions, decision-making and learning.

articles.title: Introducing MonkeysPaw - a prompt-driven web framework in Ruby
articles.author: Scott Werner
articles.summary: MonkeysPaw is a web framework that generates entire pages from prompt files. It's the first installment of the 'Works on Your Machine' series. It represents a fundamental shift in how we can think about building things in an AI-first world. The installation and usage instructions are available on Github.

articles.title: How to Fully UNLOCK the AI Future
articles.author: Brian Wang
articles.summary: A company that can fully unlock the AI future would control all aspects of what is needed for better and better AI. It would be the AI chips, energy production for larger and larger AI data centers, the key aspects of energy, data and compute for an intelligence, money and productivity flywheel. Brian Wang is a Futurist Thought Leader and Science blogger with 1 million readers per month.

articles.title: Llama 4: Meta's New Flagship AI Models
articles.author: archyde
articles.summary: Llama 4 is the latest version of Meta's large language model (LLM) family. Llama 4 Scout, Maverick and Behemoth are openly available through Llama.com and Meta's partners. The Behemoth model is still undergoing training. Meta AI is integrated across platforms like WhatsApp, Messenger, and Instagram. Its multimodal functionalities are restricted to the United States.

articles.author: Annika Kim Constantino
articles.summary: Meta has released the first models from its latest open-source artificial intelligence software Llama 4 on WhatsApp, Messenger, Instagram Direct and the Meta AI website. The biggest and most powerful model is still in training. LlamaCon AI conference will be held on April 29.

articles.title: Meta debuts new Llama 4 models, but most powerful AI model is still to come
articles.author: Annika Kim Constantino
articles.summary: Meta released the first models from its latest open-source artificial intelligence software Llama 4 on Saturday. The biggest and most powerful model is still in training. The company will host its first LlamaCon AI conference on April 29. It is also expected to announce a standalone app for its Meta AI chatbot in the second quarter.

articles.title: Tesla Optimus Has Improved Walking and Actuators
articles.author: Freedomsphoenix Readerfour
articles.summary: The walking was mastered using reinforcement learning in a digital simulation. This training approach is used by all the leading humanoid bot companies. The reports and claims from the humanoid robot companies is that training of skills is going very well and very quickly with AI/simulation training and recordings from human trainers.

articles.title: Sentient To Bring Powerful AI Search To The Masses
articles.author: Robert Lee
articles.summary: The decentralized artificial intelligence startup, Sentient, is about to launch Open Deep Search. ODS is an open-source AI search framework that uses advanced "reasoning" skills to search the web for information and answer complex questions. It can solve sophisticated problems in the same way as the most intelligent humans do, only it can do it much faster. The company plans to bring ODS to the masses in its upcoming Generative AI application Sentient Chattool, which is a free-to-use AI application built as a decentralized alternative to ChatGPT.

articles.title: Teachers Must Do All They Can To Avert an AI-Facilitated Intellectual Dark Age
articles.author: David Thunder
articles.summary: Teachers form the minds of the next generation. Artificial Intelligence is reaching the point where it has the capacity to automate and mechanise certain aspects of teaching and learning, marginalising crucial aspects of the learning process. This makes traditional teaching tools, such as the graded take-home paper, largely obsolete. Teachers and teaching institutions need to find new approaches to student assignments and evaluation.

articles.title: A stroke survivor speaks again with the help of an experimental brain-computer implant
articles.author: Laura Ungar
articles.summary: Scientists have developed a brain-computer interface that can translate thoughts about speech into spoken words in real time. The device was tested on a 47-year-old woman with quadriplegia who couldn't speak for 18 years after a stroke. She had it implanted in her brain during surgery as part of a clinical trial. It converts her intent to speak into fluent sentences. It works similarly to existing systems used to transcribe meetings or phone calls. It was partially funded by the NIH.

It's still a very limited experience, but it hints at what might be possible in the future.

articles.summary: Artificial intelligence is getting better at mimicking human language, solving problems, and even passing exams. However, it still can't replicate one of the most fundamental parts of human cognition - how humans think. The implications for the future of AI in fields like law, medicine, and education are crucial.

Hospitals express reservations about AI's ability to solve the chronic staffing shortages plaguing hospitals across the U.S. A survey of 30 hospitals revealed a consensus that while AI can assist with administrative tasks and diagnoses, the goal of halving the administrative burden is unrealistic. AI applications do less well in practice than in a model setting.

articles.title: AI Food Flaw: ChatGPT Gives Top Marks to Revolting Brownie Recipes
articles.author: Studyfinds Staff
articles.summary: ChatGPT gave high ratings to all brownie recipes, even those containing worm meal and fish oil. The AI consistently used positive words like 'trust,' 'anticipation,' and 'joy' when describing brownies. When faced with recipes containing gag-inducing ingredients, the AI gave them nearly perfect scores.

articles.title: Opinion - AI companies are commiting mass theft and hiding behind the language of ‘training'
articles.author: David Lowery
articles.summary: David Lowery is a musician, writer, producer, and musician. He questions whether artificial intelligence models 'learn' the same way as humans. He claims that they can't handle or generate novelty, they become stymied when forced to operate with uncertainty or incomplete information, and they lack empathy and any real conception of understanding.

articles.title: AI companies are commiting mass theft and hiding behind the language of ‘training'
articles.author: David Lowery
articles.summary: There is a debate about whether artificial intelligence models 'learn' the same way as humans. According to Erik J. Larson's book 'The Myth of Artificial Intelligence', they don't. They can't handle or generate novelty, they become stymied when forced to operate with uncertainty or incomplete information, and they lack empathy and any real conception of understanding. Per LeGuin, the real question we should be asking is what AI does and whether it's worth the cost.
